results.title: Work
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
Colin McKerras introduces this lesson, which centres on work. He introduces vocabulary associated with work, such as “How many days a week do you work?” and “What do you want to do when you leave school?” We see workers in a factory in Beijing and talk to school students about their future plans. The calligraphy section shows the character “to produce” and associated characters for “production”, “products” and “maternity leave” The two dramatised sections “Work or study” which depicts a Chinese family in Australia, and “Work experience” showing a student on work experience assignments, include much of the vocabulary introduced. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Work
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
Presented by Annette Shun Wah. This video is divided into five themes: ATTITUDES TO WORK; CHOICES IN THE PAST; CHOICES TODAY; ISSUES IN THE WORKPLACE; THE CHANGING NATURE OF WORK.

results.title: Work
results.creator_credit: Rachel Reichman, Susan A Stover and Tina Kacandes
results.brief_description: Slow-paced and thoughtful, “Work” tells the story of two young women living in a depressed factory town in the heartland of America, whose paths are drawn together in an unexpected way. Jenny (Cynthia Kaplan) is married to Will who works in the mill and wants to try and save his job by siding with both management and the workers, but ends up by finding himself on the outer anyway. Jenny is unemployed but makes half-hearted attempts in applying for work, most times being put down or humiliated for her lack of skills or experience. Bored and restless, Jenny finds satisfaction in the company of June (Sonja Sohn), her next door African American neighbour who is an athlete and up and coming college student. Jenny and June’s relationship blossoms into an affair of secret conversations and erotic encounters, providing a release for Jenny’s sense of futility and hopelessness and allowing her to explore her sexuality. However, in the end Jenny has no control over the direction her life will take - choices are made, and so be it. Reichman has given this film a cinema verite style and through her direction, the film has retained an essential quality of realism and truism. Cinematography by Steven Giuliano. Cast also includes Peter Sprague, Steven Garfield, Deirdre Lewis, Patt Franklin.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rachel Reichman, Susan A Stover and Tina Kacandes

results.title: Words for battle
results.brief_description: A documentary which sets to film great passages of prose and poetry relevant to the struggle of World War II. Spoken by Sir Laurence Olivier, the quotations are taken from the writings of Camden, Milton, William Blake, Robert Browning, Abraham Lincoln, Rudyard Kipling and Winston Churchill.

results.title: Words are not enough
results.creator_credit: Leon Clore, Basic Films and Fred Moore
results.brief_description: Problems of communication arise at all levels of human relationship, including management and workers. Communication structures become more complex as the distance between boardroom and shop floor increase, and as specialists and functional managers authority become confused with line management. Stimulates constructive thought and discussion rather than suggests techniques.

results.title: Words and labels
results.creator_credit: Centre for Educational Television and Lawrie Lawler
results.brief_description: Explains the methods and techniques for showing printing and writing on a television screen, including the presenter’s over handwriting. Stresses the need for good timing and rehearsals. Some suggestions are made on dealing with awkward or unusually shaped objects. Companion film to “Graphics and Superimposition”.

results.title: Word processing: kissing the girls goodbye
results.brief_description: Once upon a time there was a guy called “the boss” - it was a lonely job. He has to get his own coffee, make pone calls, write his own letters and still run his business. So he hire “his girl” or secretary to assist him whilst he ran the business. She was a kind of servant, messenger and scribe. Today there are tens of millions scattered throughout organisations. Studies have found secretaries skills are not being fully utilised but paper processing is exploding. To the rescue comes world processing and re-organising of secretarial duties.
